headline.main: A Restaurateur Kills 1 Suspect In a Robbery

docs.lead_paragraph: A Harlem restaurant owner yesterday morning shot to death one of three men who were fleeing after a robbery at the restaurant, the police said. The owner was charged with second-degree murder. The incident occurred at about 12:30 A.M. at the Strawberry Jamaican Cuisine Restaurant at 2354 Seventh Avenue, between 137th and 138th Streets.

headline.main: Far From Bangkok, but Taste Is Thai

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Recently, Thai restaurants have sprung up like mushrooms after a spring rain. Yet, they are still uncommon on Long Island, and the opening of a new Thai outpost is cause for rejoicing among lovers of this intricate and intriguing cuisine.

docs.abstract: Karla Cook reviews Ganges Authentic Indian Cuisine restaurant in Princeton Junction, NJ; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: AN ideal site for a restaurant is not under a hill and behind a building and on the way to a bath supply store. And an ideal name wouldn't conjure up an image of historically polluted waters. But it would match the quality and deliciousness of the exceedingly succulent lamb chops, the fried hot peppers stuffed with tamarind the chicken Hyderabadi and other delicacies at Ganges Authentic Indian Cuisine. And it certainly would aim to match the gentle hospitality and the enthusiasm that are hallmarks of this five-month-old restaurant.

headline.main: A New Magazine for Fledgling Cooks

docs.abstract: Cuisine, a new food magazine from August Home, is aimed at people just getting into cooking; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: CUISINE, a new food magazine, has hit the newsstands. Unrelated to the much-admired Cuisine magazine that ceased publication in 1984, this Cuisine is published by August Home, a Des Moines company that publishes how-to magazines like Woodsmith. Cuisine uses a step-by-step format illustrated with color photographs. The editor, John Meyer, a former restaurateur and chef from Atlanta, has a small team to develop and photograph the recipes. The magazine is ''for people who are just finding it interesting to get started in cooking,'' Mr. Meyer said. ''We're not going real fancy.'' But a recipe for fresh pasta includes directions for coloring it with beets, saffron, spinach or tomatoes.

docs.lead_paragraph: CHIKUBU is one of those inconspicuous midtown Japanese restaurants that I have passed dozens of times without paying much notice. Only when some Western friends who have kept it to themselves for years decided to break their code of silence, did I venture inside. First impressions were promising - at a long table in one of the two dining rooms were six tipsy Japanese businessmen, their silk ties askew and normally rigid expressions softened by saki. Judging by the gusto with which they were eating and drinking, I had high hopes. Chikubu is indeed a find in this part of town, offering some first-rate vegetable dishes, broiled entrees and casseroles. It specializes in the cuisine of Kyoto, which is known for its cooked dishes. However, exceptionally fresh sashimi is available, while sushi is served only at lunch. The narrow restaurant is trim and neat, in shades of light gray and blond wood. During my visits, the sound level was generally low, even later in the evening when a group of Oriental Boy George look-alikes sauntered in and enlivened the atmosphere. The service staff is good-natured and exceedingly polite if not always terribly efficient.

headline.main: The Dishes Are Southern, and Piled High

docs.abstract: Claudia Rowe reviews Yvonne's Southern Cuisine Restaurant in Pelham, NY; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THIS is no place for those with mincing appetites. Every plate at Yvonne's Southern Cuisine restaurant is dripping with gravy or piled high with a golden-fried mound of something, so here is fair warning: If you go, be prepared to eat. For 15 years, transplanted southerners and hungry northerners have been flocking here for Yvonne Parker's slow-cooked ribs, fried chicken and collard greens. Sometimes people come by the busload.

headline.main: Food at 35,000 Feet: A Souk of Scents

docs.abstract: Article on some food and catering services, including Carry on Cuisine and SkyMeals, that prepare meals for airline passengers to take on plane; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: IN a big wide wonderful world of clamoring cuisines, other people's take-out food has joined the long list of new experiences -- some might even say annoyances -- that airplane passengers are learning to put up with. Let me explain how we got to this point. Last year, most major domestic carriers (Continental Airlines being a prominent exception) eliminated most food service in coach cabins on most domestic flights. In response, many passengers began bringing their own food, which was sometimes made at home but more often bought at an airport fast-food restaurant.
